resources.string: Search for or look-up a Lubukusu word to view its definition in English
Word not found. Recheck spelling or look-up instead.

About

The Lubukusu-English dictionary app is based on the draft of the "Bukusu-English Dictionary" compiled and edited by Michael Marlo, Adrian Sifuna, Aggrey Wasike (2008).

The dictionary retains all the tone marking of the original source but also includes the spelling of words as commonly spelled/used.

Transcription

In the present transcription system, long vowels are marked as a sequence of two vowels, e.g., [aa]

A syllable boundary between two vowels is marked by '.'.

High-tone is marked with an acute accent.

Low-tone is unmarked, 'b' represents [b] after a nasal and [β] elsewhere, 'ch' represents [č], 'sh' represents [š], 'kh' represents [x], 'ng'' ('ng' followed by an apostrophe) represents [ŋ], 'nj' represents [ñǰ], and 'ng' represents [ŋg].

In general, 'ny' should represent the palatal nasal [ñ], although there may be cases where the same orthographic sequence represents the sequence of a coronal nasal followed by a palatal glide, i.e., [ny].

Abbreviations

The following abbreviations are used to mark parts of speech:

  'adj'   adjective

  'adv'   adverb

  'comp'   complement

  'conj'   conjunction

  'dem'   demonstrative

  'excl'   exclamation

  'ideo'   ideophone

  'loc'   locative

  'n'   noun

  'neg'   negation element

  'np'   noun phrase

  'num'   numeral

  'poss'   possessive pronoun

  'pp'   prepositional phrase

  'prep'   preposition

  'pron'   pronoun

  'quan'   quantifier

  'relcl'   relative clause

  's'   sentence

  'v'   verb

  'vint'   intransitive verb

  'vrefl'   reflexivized verb

  'vpass'   passivized verb

  'vtr'   transitive verb

  'vp'   verb phrase

  'wh'   wh- (question) element
